content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple sections of tissue, approximately 10-12 pieces, consistent with lymph nodes sampled for cancer staging. The tissues are stained with H&E and show varying sizes and shapes. Most sections exhibit a typical lymph node appearance with darker purple (basophilic) cortical areas and lighter pink (eosinophilic) medullary or fatty regions. The overall task is to systematically screen each of these lymph node sections for evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is part of the systematic evaluation of all tissue fragments on the slide. This particular fragment is a small lymph node located in the lower-left quadrant. At low power, it appears densely cellular and basophilic (dark purple), which warrants high-power examination to assess its cytoarchitectural features. The goal is to determine if this high cellularity is due to a reactive lymphoid population or a metastatic tumor deposit. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to examine every single piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node to look for evidence of metastasis. The highlighted area represents one of these tissue fragments, specifically the third one from the bottom on the left side. I am zooming in to assess its architecture, confirm it is a lymph node, and meticulously search for any atypical cells or glandular structures that would indicate the presence of metastatic colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my approach is systematic. I would start with the first lymph node at the top left of the slide. The green box is placed on the periphery (cortex) of this lymph node. This is a critical area to examine because metastatic cells from a primary tumor typically travel through the afferent lymphatic vessels and first lodge in the subcapsular sinus, located just beneath the lymph node capsule. Therefore, I am zooming into this high-yield area to begin my search for metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I need to examine every single piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node to look for metastasis. I am starting my systematic review from the top left of the slide. The highlighted area contains the first tissue fragment in this sequence. Although small, it has a basophilic (purple) component, indicating it is lymphoid tissue and must be examined at high power to rule out even microscopic deposits of tumor (micrometastasis or isolated tumor cells). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. When screening for lymph node metastasis, every lymph node must be carefully examined. I would zoom into this specific area because it represents one of the smaller, more densely basophilic (dark purple) lymph nodes, located in the lower central part of the slide. At low power, the dense, dark appearance can be suspicious for either a reactive process or a metastatic tumor deposit, which often disrupts the normal architecture and appears as a hypercellular, basophilic focus. Therefore, high-magnification review is essential to make a definitive diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each piece of tissue that could be a lymph node. The area in the green box is one of these potential nodes, located in the lower-middle part of the slide. It is small but appears very cellular (darkly stained). I would zoom in to assess the architecture and cytology at high magnification to rule out the presence of metastatic tumor cells. Every potential lymph node must be carefully inspected. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my process involves a systematic, one-by-one examination of every lymph node submitted. The green box is placed on the second lymph node from the top in the central column. I am zooming into this specific node to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high power. This is a standard procedure to meticulously search for any evidence of metastatic tumor cells, which would classify the node as 'positive'. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic, comprehensive review of every piece of tissue submitted as a lymph node. This particular fragment, located in the lower-middle left of the slide (the fourth distinct node from the top in the leftmost column), is small but appears densely cellular (very dark purple). High cellularity can be due to a benign reactive process or a metastatic deposit. It is crucial to examine such areas at high magnification to differentiate between benign lymphocytes and malignant epithelial cells, as even a small focus of metastasis is clinically significant. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol involves a systematic review of every single piece of tissue on the slide to ensure no lymph nodes are missed and each is thoroughly evaluated for metastasis. The selected area is the first tissue fragment at the top right corner. Even small fragments must be examined at high power because they could represent a lymph node or a portion of one containing a small metastatic focus. The dark staining suggests it is a cellular area requiring detailed inspection. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all tissue sections. This particular node (one of the large, centrally located ones) is a logical choice to examine. It appears densely cellular, and at this low power, it's necessary to zoom in to assess the cellular architecture, look for atypical cells, and rule out the presence of metastatic tumor deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task is to systematically examine every lymph node for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. The green box is placed on the second lymph node from the top on the right. I would zoom into this area because it represents the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, where it interfaces with the perinodal fat. This is a critical region to scrutinize, as metastatic cells often first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus, located just beneath the capsule at the edge of the node. This systematic approach ensures that even small metastatic deposits are not missed. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my approach is to systematically examine each piece of tissue. I am zooming into this area, which is part of the second lymph node from the top on the left side. This particular node appears larger and more irregularly shaped than some of the others, and it shows a heterogeneous mix of pink (stromal/fatty) and purple (cellular) areas. Such heterogeneity can be a sign of effacement of the normal lymph node architecture by a tumor. The selected area is at the periphery of the dense cellular component, a common location to find metastatic deposits in the subcapsular sinus. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The primary task is to identify lymph node metastasis. I am examining this specific lymph node (one of the larger nodes in the center-left) because it appears hypercellular and intensely basophilic on the thumbnail view. This high cellularity is a key feature to investigate at higher magnification, as it could represent a dense infiltrate of metastatic tumor cells replacing the normal lymph node parenchyma. It is crucial to differentiate this from a reactive lymphoid process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, monotonous population of small, round cells with scant cytoplasm, dark nuclei, and condensed chromatin. These features are characteristic of mature lymphocytes. The lymphoid tissue is adjacent to mature adipose tissue on the right. There are no signs of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli, or desmoplastic stromal reaction. My impression is that this is a benign lymph node, negative for metastatic disease.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a small lymph node. There is a dense aggregate of small, dark, monotonous-appearing cells, which are lymphocytes, characteristic of lymphoid tissue. This lymphoid tissue is surrounded by and partially intermixed with mature adipose tissue (fat). I do not see any large, atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or extensive necrosis that would be suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign (negative) lymph node, showing no evidence of metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node on the right (pink tissue). To the left of the capsule, within the lymph node parenchyma, there is a dense infiltrate of small, dark lymphocytes. Crucially, embedded within this lymphoid tissue are several well-formed, back-to-back glandular structures. These glands are composed of atypical columnar epithelial cells and are inconsistent with normal lymph node architecture. Their appearance is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. The tumor is located in the subcapsular/cortical region of the node.
This is ROI 4. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of a lymph node. On the left, there is a dense collection of lymphoid cells, which appear to be mature lymphocytes. This lymphoid tissue is being replaced by mature adipose tissue (fat), which is visible on the right. This process is known as fatty infiltration and is a benign finding. I do not see any nests of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or other features of metastasis. Therefore, my impression is that this is a benign lymph node fragment, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a lymph node with preserved, but reactive, architecture. There are numerous well-defined lymphoid follicles of varying sizes, indicative of follicular hyperplasia. Additionally, there are scattered deposits of black, irregular pigment, which is anthracotic pigment (carbon), a common and benign finding in regional lymph nodes. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or cohesive nests of tumor cells to suggest metastasis. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a portion of a lymph node directly adjacent to adipose tissue (fat cells at the top). The tissue consists of a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are no definitive features of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells, or necrotic debris. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node. I would classify this specific area as negative for malignancy and continue to examine the rest of this node and the other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image reveals a dense population of lymphoid cells, which are the small, dark purple cells. The overall architecture of a lymph node appears preserved, with follicles and interfollicular zones. There are scattered deposits of black, irregular, acellular pigment, which is consistent with anthracosis (carbon pigment), a common and benign finding in lymph nodes draining the gastrointestinal tract. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or significant cytologic atypia that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign (negative) lymph node with reactive features and anthracosis.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a dense, monotonous population of small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and dark, round nuclei. These are characteristic features of mature lymphocytes. The tissue architecture is that of lymphoid parenchyma. At the bottom of the image, there is mature adipose tissue (fat cells), which is common in and around lymph nodes. I do not see any large, atypical cells, glandular formation, cribriform structures, or significant necrosis that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a benign lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of a lymph node adjacent to and infiltrated by mature adipose tissue (fat). There is a dense population of small, round, dark-staining cells, consistent with lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or mucin pools that would be characteristic of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is a benign lymph node that is negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node. It is composed of dense lymphoid tissue with follicular structures, some showing reactive germinal centers. There are prominent deposits of black, granular, extracellular pigment, which is consistent with anthracotic pigment (carbon) or tattoo ink used to mark a lesion. On the right, there is perinodal adipose tissue. I do not see any atypical glands, nests of malignant cells, or other features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node with pigment deposition, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 11. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the interface between the lymph node parenchyma and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. The top left corner is composed of a dense sheet of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes. There are also some black pigment deposits (anthracotic pigment), which is a common, benign finding. The rest of the image consists of mature adipose tissue (fat cells). The boundary is well-defined. In this specific field of view, I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or other features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this area is that it is a benign lymph node margin. The pathologist would proceed to examine the rest of the node and all other nodes on the slide to make a final determination.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is largely replaced by a dense lymphoid infiltrate that is extensively infiltrated by malignant glands. These glands are irregular in shape and size, lined by atypical epithelial cells, and are characteristic of adenocarcinoma. The presence of these back-to-back and infiltrating glands within lymphoid tissue is definitive evidence of metastatic carcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals that the high cellularity is due to a dense and diffuse infiltrate of small, monotonous lymphocytes that efface the normal nodal architecture. I can see some residual, paler lymphoid follicles (proliferation centers) and scattered black anthracotic pigment within macrophages. Importantly, there are no definitive features of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands or nests of malignant epithelial cells. My impression is that this lymph node is negative for metastatic colorectal cancer. However, the monotonous lymphoid infiltrate is atypical and raises suspicion for a co-existent lymphoproliferative disorder, such as small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) or chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) involving the node, which would be an incidental but clinically significant finding.
